@AprilynneA I know what you mean.

I was running a content marketing agency so I had no shortage of stuff to write for work. And I complained about it too 😂

I've been using them to welcome new followers & ask what content they'd like to see in the future.

Result?

My content is more targeted & engagement is higher than ever! 🚀

@PeterHolzer16 You're absolutely right.

It's important not to isolate yourself though.

Many times we think our ideas or what we make is unique when in reality it's just a slightly modified version of something that already exists.

It's important to look around you before jumping in :)

The worst mistake I made growing up was thinking there was a threshold to success in life.

That after that point, everything would be easier. Tough luck, because that point doesn't exist.

Like failure, success isn't a one-time thing. It can happen again, and again, and again 😉

8️⃣ Putting up walls is crucial

➡️ If you don't decide, someone will decide for you.

That applies to your startup as well.
If you don't put up walls, anything goes.

You should listen to customers.
But they are buying YOUR product.

Make them aware of what they can't ask for. https://t.co/7rqHYsknjS

7️⃣ Business plans are worthless

➡️ Make a pitch deck instead.

"But you just told me funding isn't worth it!"

True, but I'm also telling you:

» Learn how to sell.

The best brands develop great positioning AND a great sales pitch. It's not either/or. Together, they do wonders. https://t.co/Ano4uVNCsv

6️⃣ Getting funded isn't worth it 9 times out of 10

➡️ Nobody likes to work under a lot of stress.

But it's what you'll experience under funding.

Bootstrapping gives you a virtually infinite runway.
Trading it for quick cash just isn't worth it.

(I tried—wouldn't bother again) https://t.co/xA3Z8dobgz

5️⃣ Positioning is everything

➡️ "I don't get it—I'm out"

That's most people when they visit your site.
Hard to accept but it's true.

Positioning is often misunderstood.

It's not about "knowing" your audience—it's about giving them what they want in a language they understand. https://t.co/rmHCwWQtY2

4️⃣ Perfect pricing doesn't exist

➡️ Every single customer is different...

...no matter how much you try to put them in a box.

There is no such thing as "perfect" pricing.
There's good pricing & bad pricing:

» The 1st focuses on value
» The 2nd hinges on tactics

You choose. https://t.co/Q2p1LTsNlh

3️⃣ Growth is scarier than you think

➡️ "What if I'm not able to deliver?"

These thoughts would often creep up.

Growth is equal parts exciting and scary.
But to me, the scary parts were overpowering.

How did I manage them?
Simple, I didn't.

You can't control the unknown. https://t.co/xCI6p6TObg

2️⃣ "Turning the corner" is a myth

➡️ I've spent 2 years hoping to "turn the corner."

Guess what.

There was never a corner to begin with.

The more you grow, the farther the corner feels.
So, how do you close that gap?

With good management practices.

(& some thick skin) https://t.co/N801QpnVuK

At its peak, my startup made $8,000 per month.

Here are 8 lessons I've learned growing it, visualized:

1️⃣ Starting is the hardest

➡️ It truly feels like pushing a boulder up a hill.

Sure, it gets easier.
But it never gets "easy."

Managing your expectations is VERY important. https://t.co/jypOpFMOxb

#1 rule to growing on Twitter:

👉🏼 Don't complain

3. Start an artistic hobby

You'll come back energized in no time!

4️⃣ Comparison stifles growth

➡️ Our brains are hard-wired towards comparison

If you can't escape it—learn to ignore it.

You can't control what others will do.
But you CAN ignore them.

Don't give in to their need for attention.
Don't comment either.

Simply ignore and move on. https://t.co/agj6VCXiXK

3️⃣ Money means commitment

➡️ "[Enter unpaid task], it should be easy for you!"

Ever heard this sentence?

Perhaps from a family member.

How many times did you commit to unpaid labour?

Money means more than just "work."

It means: 

"I respect you, please respect me too." https://t.co/Sy8IT3OBlT

2️⃣ The only constant is change

➡️ You likely consider yourself a specialist

But you're MUCH more than that.

Growing up, you wouldn't hear yourself say:
"Mom, I want to be a conversion rate expert."

It's great you are one NOW.

But it doesn't mean you have to be one forever. https://t.co/Kb3W2Cc9MD

1️⃣ Writing solves problems

➡️ Problem-solving is counter intuitive

Why spend hours writing stuff down when your problem isn't manifested on paper?

The answer is simple:

ALL human problems derive from assumption. Writing exhausts those assumptions, leading you to the solution. https://t.co/BjkqbCQngP

8️⃣ Sell to someone you trust

➡️ Your gut is a powerful tool

Use it.

If something smells fishy about the deal, or you don't fully trust the person for whatever reason, DROP IT.

The biggest regret you will have is selling to someone that won't do your years-long work justice. https://t.co/hTlH1ipf8L

7️⃣ Learn to negotiate

➡️ I sold my startup in 5 days

It should have taken a LOT longer than that.

Learn to negotiate; don't give in to anything the buyer throws at you even if the promise of quick cash is tempting.

Be rational even if you feel strong emotions. https://t.co/GAYxvIixmu

6️⃣ Offer support separately

➡️ You're not a commodity

If you include support as part of the main sale agreement, you risk your buyer treating your services as a product. 

They'll just use you as much as they can.

Instead, offer them SEPARATELY.

(& paid on an hourly basis) https://t.co/GBkFJ3J1vL

5️⃣ Pay attention to non-competes

➡️ 3 years is longer than you think

If you sign a non-compete blindly, you're giving the buyer permission to make claims on any potentially competing offering for a long time.

ALWAYS negotiate non-competes down to ~6 months. https://t.co/tsVEyUR1eo

4️⃣ Profits are everything

➡️ There's a reason why buyers ask for a "P&L"...

… and not your Stripe numbers.

The Profit & Loss statement tells a story about the financial health of your business. It's the most important document you'll ever produce.

Don't skimp on it. https://t.co/ATrvVpR85S

3️⃣ Don't publish the listing publicly

➡️ Your startup is your baby

You don't want just ANYONE buying it.

Always sell it privately.

(@microacquire is great for that) https://t.co/GlzndSqZGr

2️⃣ Ask for advice from an attorney

➡️ Attorneys are expensive

But it's even more expensive to throw a months-long deal down the drain. Ask for advice before you sign ANYTHING. https://t.co/DSvn4kotbl

8 months ago I sold my startup for $45,000.

Here are 8 lessons learned, visualized:

1️⃣ Take it seriously

➡️ Selling a business is a LEGAL transaction

Rushing it means exposing yourself to potential lawsuits. Don't underestimate any part of the process. https://t.co/A5fBBcWtAC

@TomRyanRPP @arvidkahl 3. Start with 2 pricing options

The idea is to give all info in ONE page.

Writers are busy, respecting their time goes a long way.

Plus, good briefs makes them WANT to work with you.

Raise your hand as a reply if you want a template 👇🏼

Will send it over if enough people are interested!

In the bottom half, provide the info that doesn't change.

Who's your target audience?

What's their pain point? (Very important)

What are they interested in? Liked brands?

Give a short description of the audience and YOUR brand, provide bullets for tone of voice.

[Continues] https://t.co/B13pevNEC8

Start with the topic you have in mind.

Break it down into a sub-topic.

Is it a guide? A list? A comparison?

Write a short description.

And to REALLY hit the nail on its head, tell the writer what angle to take. It takes a few minutes but it's totally worth it.

[Continues] https://t.co/fqOLtzKLzZ

Want to work with writers?

Make their life easier with a content brief.

All you need is:

1. Information on the topic
2. Notes on the angle to take
3. A description of your audience
4. A brief bio of your brand
+ a full outline (bonus)

All wrapped up in 1 single PDF file!

🧵 https://t.co/xNyLGWmrxk

1️⃣ Pick 5 topics relevant to you (e.g. "SaaS"),

Before sending out the email, I published all videos that I had made up to that point on YouTube and sent them out to all subscribers.

It's not exactly what I had promised, but it was something.
So, even if my subscriber count was steadily growing, I decided to cut the series short. But I didn't want to go back empty-handed... https://t.co/mAW3G7F9qL

As soon as the emails started pouring in, I felt a huge sense of relief. People actually recognized the effort!

It wasn't just about the end goal for them.

It was about the journey to get there.

In my head, I was thinking:

"I've made a promise to these people, what should I do?"

1. Push through and burn out, or;
2. Be honest and tell the truth.

I opted for the latter, and I'm happy I did: https://t.co/LGF7hp5Hcn

I'd worked really hard up to that point to keep people updated, & it did feel like I would have made it. But life got in the way:

  » My full-time job was eating up my energy
  » I struggled with explaining concepts
  » Videos are just plain hard to make

I've edited 100s of blog posts in my career.

A very common mistake I see is making assumptions:

"By now, you should be aware of..."

"As a X professional, you must know that..."

This alienates the reader.

It comes through as condescending.

When you write, don't assume.

@FrancescoCiull4 Yep, I'm in this phase. I had a spurt of this back in 2014 when I was studying web design and then again when I got into full-stack web development 5 months ago. Not quitting this time though :)

@YehudaZahler I used one for years from 2014 to 2016. I honestly loved it—never got slower and did what it had to. But as soon as my career got to a point where I needed professional software, it became pretty much useless.

Focus 🎯

In the early days of starting something new, it's REALLY hard to focus. Instead of asking yourself:

- What niche to choose
- Which tech to leverage

Ask yourself:

- Who can I help get X done?
- How can I add value?

Don't get it mixed.

Start with who you serve 1st 🤝
@dagorenouf No need to ask for permission to family and friends, you're doing what YOU want to do, that's all that matters :)

Speaking things into existence

It's a concept I've applied for years

1. Set a goal (eg launch a SaaS)
2. Get a high-level understanding of it
3. Forget the details - speak it into existence

If you get others to sign up to your vision, you are now obligated to make it happen :)

If you're thinking about launching your own startup, or if you're already working on a project, get other people involved as soon as you can.

It's the effort of looking for help that should guide the processes you build—NOT the other way around.

(The end 🙃)

This taught me a key thing, and one that I have learned the hard way; people ALWAYS come before processes.

You can have a well-oiled machine, but if there are no people to operate it, it's about as useful as a door stopper.

(Last tweet 👇🏼)

I needed to hire!

Not that day, not a week before, but 2 months prior!

All the additional onboarding load meant I couldn't  focus on what I already had to maintain. Things became hasty, and the hiring efforts I was able to put in were too little and too late.

(Almost there 👇🏼)

Until that point, I had enjoyed stable but slow growth.

There were parts of the system which were going out to contractors, but I was still taking on 90%+ of the responsibility.

And as soon as 5 new customers joined in <1 week, it  finally became clear to me...

(Continues 👇🏼)

The biggest failure for me was not recognizing this trend soon enough, thinking that I could take on more responsibility.

After all, I had set up the processes, new customers were coming in every month—things were working out!

But growth is a tricky thing...

(Continues 👇🏼)

For me, the line would end in 2 occasions:

  1. I didn't have the time to do something
  2. I was really bad at doing something

The more my startup grew, the more frequently both occasions would come up. First once in a while, then on a regular basis.

(Continues 👇🏼)

When you start your own business from scratch, it's normal to feel like you are responsible for it all.

But it's important to recognize where that line of "must be responsible at all costs" ends.

(Continues 👇🏼)

In the 2 years that I've spent building and growing my previous startup to $10k MRR at its peak, I've learned a TON.

But the most important thing I learned is that you can't go at it alone. You have to start with a mentality of "we".

When you have an hour to spare, ask yourself those same 3 questions. They're not as trivial as you think.

And if you feel like sharing, reply with your own findings! Zero judgment, I want to help however I can 🤙🏼

Dumping your brain on a piece of paper is a fantastic way to get CLARITY in your life.

It helps you filter out the 💩 and get to the 💎!

Making a habit of writing gets you this close to achieving great things 🤏🏼 All you have to do after is act on them.

(Almost there 🙃)

In ~1 hour of brain dumping, I'd given myself the answer to what I couldn't solve for YEARS in my life.

All thanks to 3 questions + a piece of paper 📝

That would've never happened hadn't I just started writing. And I'm confident it'd work the same for you.

(Continues 👇🏼)

After a bit of rearranging, the answer became clear:

"I want to make an impact at a large scale (dream) by building a sustainable business (achievement) with the goal of helping others and myself grow for the long-term (the why)."

This was truly groundbreaking!

(Continues 👇🏼)

I answered as best as I could...

...only to end up with long-winded rants 🙄

But in those rants, some words stood out the most:

"Make an impact at a large scale"

"Build for the long-term"

"Be independent"

So I started piecing them together...

(Continues 👇🏼)

Recently I was asked to write down the answer to 3 simple questions:

1. What is your lifetime dream?
2. What do you want to achieve?
3. Why do you want to achieve it?

At first, I thought it was just motivational 💩

But then I gave them a shot...

If you're planning to launch your own project in 2021, think about the person on the other side. What value are you delivering that they can't find anywhere else? Can you deliver all the way through? As @law4 puts it, you have to serve before you sell.

It's been about a year now since I've launched @KoalaRank and I wouldn't have made it without the support of clients who believed there was something of real value behind the curtains. It's what keeps me going, and it's what I want to keep delivering.

I recently read a post from an Indie Hacker who decided to quit after a year of trying without much success. And I simpathize, I've had that feeling of wanting to quit so many times. But it's the fact that I truly care about delivering value that helps me push through.

I've always believed in resilience, and I don't think it gets talked about enough in startup world. I've met many people in the scene who were hyper enthusiastic about an idea, only to drop it as soon as they realized how much work had to go into it...

My favorite part about content marketing is creating and managing the strategies. It's challenging but extremely fun to look at the different audiences and figure out which topics they're interested in most through search data 🤓

Finish what you've started.

If you don't have the resources to start something big, do something tiny. Give yourself a deadline and stick to it. Finishing is a skill in itself and no matter how bad the end result, you'll end up learning from your mistakes.

CONTENT TIP

Use a hook in your introductions.

People take 7-10 seconds to understand whether your blog post looks decent and 20-30 seconds to decide whether they want to read the whole thing. Give them a reason to with a punchy headline and a strong hook.

Plan your marketing around value, not buzzwords. 

Clients will stick around far longer that way.

This is not cool.

You don't pay freelancers a fixed price to tell them how to get their job done. You pay them to complete one task through THEIR expertise paired with your internal assets. 

Don't have any assets to work with?

Don't hire a freelancer.

It's as simple as that.

Scope creep is a problem of trust.

If the client doesn't trust you with the final outcome in the specified timeframe, they will start bossing you around telling you how you should get things done and often extending the scope of the original project.

/4

If they insist with their larger vision for the original price (and often timeframe), deprioritize, communicate a longer timeframe, and get back to doing things the way YOU'd do them—not the other way around.

/3

New projects are exciting.

Scope creep isn't. 

If your client just won't understand that quality of work will suffer from continuously changing the plan, the game is not worth the candle. Let the client know that the project has gone off track and discuss a solution.

/2

Scope creep happens.

I've written 100s of pieces in my career as a content writer and I can tell you that no matter how careful I am with requirements, some clients will just keep adding stuff pretending that it's part of the original plan.

What to do?

Deprioritize.

/1

The takeaway:

> Only start a business if you feel a burning desire to fix stuff for the better and help others succeed in life. If you're doing it for the cool factor, you will eventually hit a bottleneck due to stress, lack of motivation, and/or unhappy customers.

#Startup

I'm not trying to bring you down with this.

Seriously, if you want that shiny landing page, go for it! 

But I want you to understand that starting a business is NOT that cool. 

Exciting? Yes.
Ambitious? Absolutely.
Potentially life-changing? Yep.

But definitely NOT cool.

/9

My story of entrepreneurship is a story of NEED.

After 1 year of constant work, I don't wake up thinking: "Oh gee, what a great year. No paid time off, countless hours of self-education, brainstorming, experimenting... I want more of that!"

Yet I continue pushing through.

/8

Founders: 

If you you feel like months of research and early-adopter feedback agony is a chore not worth your time, you're not fit for the role.

You will be stressed.
You will want to pull your hair out.
You will (probably) cry.

But that should NEVER be enough to stop you.

/7

Today, Koala Rank is still a small business.

But it IS working. It's making me more money than I could ever imagine.

However, its inception was as much a labor of love as it was a labor of NEED.

And this is where I'm getting at with this thread...

/6

That's when Koala Rank came to be.

I spent SIX MONTHS cooking up the business model, figuring out the angle and whether I needed a business plan or not, what market I was targeting, and so on.

All of this with no fancy landing page.

Just me, a pen, and lots of paper.

Translation Domain was just a blog... It had the potential to make me money, but it would be stuck in the never-ending loop of: "How do I monetize this? How do I monetize that?" 

No thanks.

How was I supposed to show that I knew what I was doing if I didn't have my own blog? Something that could demonstrate my knowledge of SEO and content marketing? That's when I built @TranslationDom.

/3

I've always had a maker mindset.

I knew I wanted to build something but I didn't quite know what that was. That held true until I got so frustrated with freelancing platforms that I HAD to build something. ANYTHING that would take me out of there.

So I built @KoalaRank.

/2

But I wanted to take it a step further.

#ContentWriting doesn't have to be tedious.

Do this:

1. Research the topic
2. Gather your sources
3. Actually READ a few of them in full
3. Jot down bulleted notes as you read
4. Comment with your professional take
5. Plug the notes into the body of your #outline

.

Mentioning people in your posts is crucial.

Always prepare to get in contact with influencers before or after releasing a new post. 

Publishing into the void doesn't help.

Close the process by reviewing the format and prepare a list of promotional tasks before you hit publish.

Working on a stupid-long #BlogPost over @KoalaRank.

Want to know how to get this done efficiently?

1. Write outline

2. Format CMS skeleton

3. Research topic

4. Fill in intro/outro

5. Research #influencers

6. Fill in rest of post

7. Make media

8. On-page #SEO

9. Done! https://t.co/MWuag0OJGe

Stop trying to rush through #content.

With each piece of content you publish, you should run a mini marketing campaign.

Think about who you can mention in your post, link back to them, and THEN reach out. 

Offer them value for their #audience and they'll thank you for it!

Starting with manual work is OK.

I think a lot of us are obsessed with #automation.

Yes, it is important. And yes, it does help.

But having that connection with people is paramount when you're first starting out with your biz.

Don't forget you're talking to people, not bots!
